p.s: Description of Glycomyces tenuis sp. nov.
Glycomyces tenuis (te' nu. is. L. adj. tenuis, thin)
The vegetative hyphae are very thin (diameter, 0.15 to 0.40 μm), long, densely branched, and white or sometimes cream or slightly pink.

The spores, which are borne singly or in chains, are oval or spherical (0.3 to 0.6 by 0.4 to 0.8 μm) or (rarely) rod shaped (length, 0.3 to 0.7 μm); the spore diameter exceeds the hypha diameter (Fig. 1).
Aerial mycelium is not formed.
Cultures grow well on rich organic media.
When cells are grown on synthetic media, yeast extract or Casamino Acids (0.3%) must be added.
The temperature growth range is 10 to 40°C.
The cell wall chemotype is chemotype II (meso-diaminopimelic acid, glycine, arabinose, and xylose).
Glycerolteichoic acid is also present in the cell wall (5).
The peptidoglycan contains alanine, glutamic acid, glycine, meso-diaminopimelic acid, glucosamine, and muramic acid (molar ratio, 1.0:1.1:0.85:1.0:1.07:2.0).
The glycine is probably combined with glutamic acid and arranged in a tetrapeptide chain, not in an interpeptide bridge.
The linkage of tetrapeptide chains is directly between the meso-diaminopimelic acid of one chain and the terminal alanine of the other.
The peptidoglycan type is type A1, (15).
Nitrogen-containing phospholipids are absent, although phosphatidylinositol, cardiolipin, and phosphatidylinositolmannoside are present (type PI phospholipid pattern).

The predominant fatty acids include the following saturated branched iso acids (up to 35% of the total fatty acids) and anteiso acids (up to 48% of the total fatty acids): 13-methyltetradecanoic acid (iso-15:O acid), 10.3%; 12-methyl-tetradecanoic acid (anteiso-15:O acid), 19.4%; 14-methyl-pentadecanoic acid (iso-160 acid), 23.1%; and 15-methyl-hexadecanoic (iso-17:0 acid), 24.0%.
The percentages of all other fatty acids are less than 10% (Table 2).
The predominant menaquinones are menaquinones with hexahydrogenated isoprenoid chains having 9, 10, and 11 isoprene units [MK-9(H6), MK-1O(H6), and MK-11(H6)].
The relative amounts of menaquinones MK-9(H4,H8), MK-1O(H4,H8), and MK-11(H4,H8) are noteworthy.
MK-7(H?) and MK-8(H?) are present in trace quantities (the degree of hydrogenation was not determined) (Table 1).
The guanine-plus-cytosine content of the DNA is 72 mol%.
Hydrolyzes arbutin, esculin, hypoxanthine, casein, starch, and hippurate; does not hydrolyze tyrosine or urea.
Utilizes as carbon sources and produces acid from L-arabinose, D-galactose, D-xylose, lactose, maltose, L-rhamnose, raffinose, sucrose, and D-fructose.
Does not produce acid from adonitol, D-arabinose, dulcitol, inositol, mannitol, melibiose, sorbitol, or sorbose.
Decarboxylates acetate and lactate.
Does not utilize aconitate, benzoate, citrate, oxalate, malate, succinate, tartrate, formate, or fumarate; does not utilize alanine, histidine, or leucine as a nitrogen source.
Does not grow in lysozyme broth.
Grows in the presence of 5% NaCl.

Resistant to 5 μg of oligomycin per ml, 1 μg of novobiocin per ml, and the following antibiotics at concentrations less than 1 μg/ml: carbenicillin, erythromycin, streptomycin, tetracycline, rifampin, and ristomycin.

Does not grow in the presence of 10 μg of streptomycin per ml, 5 μg of tobramycin per ml, 10 μg of erythromycin per ml, 1 μg of ristomycin per ml, 10-4% crystal violet, 0.01% phenol, 10-3% methylene blue, or 0.1% sodium azide.
No antibiotic activity is observed when the agar block method and test strains of Bacillus mycoides, Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, Sarcina lutea, and Saccharomyces cerevisiae are used.
Isolated from an association with Streptomyces galilaeus INA 5888, a soil isolate.
The type strain of G. tenuis is strain VKM Ac-1250 (=INA n-5888).

G. tenuis could be differentiated from G. rutgersensis and G. harbinensis by its thin hyphae (diameter 0.15 to 0.40 μm) with spore chains on the substrate mycelium, by its color, by the absence of aerial hyphae, and by its menaquinone composition.
A number of strain VKM Ac-1250T physiological characteristics were compared with those of two other Glycomyces species.

On the whole, G. tenuis is characterized by a broader spectrum of susceptibility to antibiotics and growth inhibitors compared with the type strains of G. rutgersensis and G. garbinensis and a narrower range of nutritional compounds utilized (Table 1).

The low level of DNA-DNA relatedness between G. tenuis VKM Ac-1250T and Streptomyces galilaeus INA 5888, from which the former organism was isolated, suggests that the presence of spontaneous variants with altered cell wall chemotypes is unlikely.

Thus, as suggested previously (19), the possibility of perpetuation of two different organisms within a common actinomycete colony deserves the attention of workers interested in variability among actinomycetes.
